trans-unit.source: Network Resource Provider
trans-unit.target: Network Resource Provider

trans-unit.source: Network Resource Provider
trans-unit.target: Network Resource Provider

trans-unit.source: Network Resource Provider
trans-unit.target: Network Resource Provider

trans-unit.source: An underpinning need in today’s business success, is the ability to build and manage large scale network aware applications in an agile, flexible, secure and repeatable way.
trans-unit.target: An underpinning need in today’s business success, is the ability to build and manage large scale network aware applications in an agile, flexible, secure and repeatable way.

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager (ARM) enables you to create such applications, as a single collection of resources in resource groups.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager (ARM) enables you to create such applications, as a single collection of resources in resource groups.

trans-unit.source: Such resources are managed through various resource providers under ARM.
trans-unit.target: Such resources are managed through various resource providers under ARM.

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager (ARM) enables you to create such applications and the associated collection of network resources as a single collection of resources in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager (ARM) enables you to create such applications and the associated collection of network resources as a single collection of resources in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: The application and the network resources run as a single unit in an ARM resource group.
trans-unit.target: The application and the network resources run as a single unit in an ARM resource group.

trans-unit.source: You can manage networking resources by using any of the following management interfaces:
trans-unit.target: You can manage networking resources by using any of the following management interfaces:

trans-unit.source: REST based API
trans-unit.target: REST based API

trans-unit.source: PowerShell
trans-unit.target: PowerShell

trans-unit.source: .NET SDK
trans-unit.target: .NET SDK

trans-unit.source: Node.JS SDK
trans-unit.target: Node.JS SDK

trans-unit.source: Java SDK
trans-unit.target: Java SDK

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: ARM template language
trans-unit.target: ARM template language

trans-unit.source: With the introduction of Network Resource Providers, you can take advantage of the following benefits:
trans-unit.target: With the introduction of Network Resource Providers, you can take advantage of the following benefits:

trans-unit.source: Metadata – you can add information to resources using tags.
trans-unit.target: Metadata – you can add information to resources using tags.

trans-unit.source: These tags can be used to track resource utilization across resource groups and subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: These tags can be used to track resource utilization across resource groups and subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Greater control of your network - network resources are loosely coupled and you can control them in a more granular fashion.
trans-unit.target: Greater control of your network - network resources are loosely coupled and you can control them in a more granular fashion.

trans-unit.source: This means you have more flexibility in managing the networking resources.
trans-unit.target: This means you have more flexibility in managing the networking resources.

trans-unit.source: Faster configuration - because network resources are loosely coupled, you can create and orchestrate network resources in parallel.
trans-unit.target: Faster configuration - because network resources are loosely coupled, you can create and orchestrate network resources in parallel.

trans-unit.source: This has drastically reduced configuration time.
trans-unit.target: This has drastically reduced configuration time.

trans-unit.source: Role Based Access Control - RBAC provides default roles, with specific security scope, in addition to allowing the creation of custom roles for secure management.
trans-unit.target: Role Based Access Control - RBAC provides default roles, with specific security scope, in addition to allowing the creation of custom roles for secure management.

trans-unit.source: Easier management and deployment - it’s easier to deploy and manage applications since you can can create an entire application stack as a single collection of resources in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Easier management and deployment - it’s easier to deploy and manage applications since you can can create an entire application stack as a single collection of resources in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: And faster to deploy, since you can deploy by simply providing a template JSON payload.
trans-unit.target: And faster to deploy, since you can deploy by simply providing a template JSON payload.

trans-unit.source: Rapid customization - you can use declarative-style templates to enable repeatable and rapid customization of deployments.
trans-unit.target: Rapid customization - you can use declarative-style templates to enable repeatable and rapid customization of deployments.

trans-unit.source: Repeatable customization - you can use declarative-style templates to enable repeatable and rapid customization of deployments.
trans-unit.target: Repeatable customization - you can use declarative-style templates to enable repeatable and rapid customization of deployments.

trans-unit.source: Network resources
trans-unit.target: Network resources

trans-unit.source: You can now manage network resources independently, instead of having them all managed through a single compute resource (a virtual machine).
trans-unit.target: You can now manage network resources independently, instead of having them all managed through a single compute resource (a virtual machine).

trans-unit.source: This ensures a higher degree of flexibility and agility in composing a complex and large scale infrastructure in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: This ensures a higher degree of flexibility and agility in composing a complex and large scale infrastructure in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: The diagram below illustrates a high-level view of the network resource model and its associations.
trans-unit.target: The diagram below illustrates a high-level view of the network resource model and its associations.

trans-unit.source: Top level resources are colored with a blue outline.
trans-unit.target: Top level resources are colored with a blue outline.

trans-unit.source: In addition to top level resources, you can see child resources colored with a gray outline.
trans-unit.target: In addition to top level resources, you can see child resources colored with a gray outline.

trans-unit.source: You can manage each resource individually.
trans-unit.target: You can manage each resource individually.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Network resource model</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Network resource model</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A conceptual view of a sample deployment involving a multi-tiered application is presented below.
trans-unit.target: A conceptual view of a sample deployment involving a multi-tiered application is presented below.

trans-unit.source: All network resources are colored with a blue outline.
trans-unit.target: All network resources are colored with a blue outline.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Network resource model</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Network resource model</linkText>

trans-unit.source: REST API
trans-unit.target: REST API

trans-unit.source: As mentioned earlier, network resources can be managed via a variety of interfaces, including REST API,.NET SDK, Node.JS SDK, Java SDK, PowerShell, CLI, Azure Portal and templates.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned earlier, network resources can be managed via a variety of interfaces, including REST API,.NET SDK, Node.JS SDK, Java SDK, PowerShell, CLI, Azure Portal and templates.

trans-unit.source: The Rest API’s conform to the HTTP 1.1 protocol specification.
trans-unit.target: The Rest API’s conform to the HTTP 1.1 protocol specification.

trans-unit.source: The general URI structure of the API is presented below:
trans-unit.target: The general URI structure of the API is presented below:

trans-unit.source: And the parameters in braces represent the following elements:
trans-unit.target: And the parameters in braces represent the following elements:

trans-unit.source: subscription-id - your Azure subscription id.
trans-unit.target: subscription-id - your Azure subscription id.

trans-unit.source: resource-provider-namespace - namespace for the provider being used.
trans-unit.target: resource-provider-namespace - namespace for the provider being used.

trans-unit.source: THe value for the network resource provider is Microsoft.Network.
trans-unit.target: THe value for the network resource provider is Microsoft.Network.

trans-unit.source: region-name - the Azure region name
trans-unit.target: region-name - the Azure region name

trans-unit.source: The following HTTP methods are supported when making calls to the REST API:
trans-unit.target: The following HTTP methods are supported when making calls to the REST API:

trans-unit.source: PUT - used to create a resource of a given type, modify a resource property or change an association between resources.
trans-unit.target: PUT - used to create a resource of a given type, modify a resource property or change an association between resources.

trans-unit.source: GET - used to retrieve information for a provisioned resource.
trans-unit.target: GET - used to retrieve information for a provisioned resource.

trans-unit.source: DELETE - used to delete an existing resource.
trans-unit.target: DELETE - used to delete an existing resource.

trans-unit.source: Both the request and response conform to a JSON payload format.
trans-unit.target: Both the request and response conform to a JSON payload format.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see <link><linkText>Azure Resource Management APIs</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more details, see <link><linkText>Azure Resource Management APIs</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: ARM template language
trans-unit.target: ARM template language

trans-unit.source: In addition to managing resources imperatively (via APIs or SDK), you can also use a declarative programming style to build and manage network resources by using the ARM Template Language.
trans-unit.target: In addition to managing resources imperatively (via APIs or SDK), you can also use a declarative programming style to build and manage network resources by using the ARM Template Language.

trans-unit.source: A sample representation of a template is provided below –
trans-unit.target: A sample representation of a template is provided below –

trans-unit.source: The template is primarily a JSON description of the resources and the instance values injected via parameters.
trans-unit.target: The template is primarily a JSON description of the resources and the instance values injected via parameters.

trans-unit.source: The example below can be used to create a virtual network with 2 subnets.
trans-unit.target: The example below can be used to create a virtual network with 2 subnets.

trans-unit.source: You have the option of providing the parameter values manually when using a template, or you can use a parameter file.
trans-unit.target: You have the option of providing the parameter values manually when using a template, or you can use a parameter file.

trans-unit.source: The example below shows a possible set of parameter values to be used with the template above:
trans-unit.target: The example below shows a possible set of parameter values to be used with the template above:

trans-unit.source: The main advantages of using templates are:
trans-unit.target: The main advantages of using templates are:

trans-unit.source: You can build a complex infrastructure in a resource group in a declarative style.
trans-unit.target: You can build a complex infrastructure in a resource group in a declarative style.

trans-unit.source: The orchestration of creating the resources, including dependency management, is handled by ARM.
trans-unit.target: The orchestration of creating the resources, including dependency management, is handled by ARM.

trans-unit.source: The infrastructure can be created in a repeatable way across various regions and within a region by simply changing parameters.
trans-unit.target: The infrastructure can be created in a repeatable way across various regions and within a region by simply changing parameters.

trans-unit.source: The declarative style leads to shorter lead time in building the templates and rolling out the infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: The declarative style leads to shorter lead time in building the templates and rolling out the infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: For sample templates, see <link><linkText>Azure quickstart templates</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For sample templates, see <link><linkText>Azure quickstart templates</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the ARM Template Language, see <link><linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on the ARM Template Language, see <link><linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The sample template above uses the virtual network and subnet resources.
trans-unit.target: The sample template above uses the virtual network and subnet resources.

trans-unit.source: There are other network resources you can use as listed below:
trans-unit.target: There are other network resources you can use as listed below:

trans-unit.source: NIC
trans-unit.target: NIC

trans-unit.source: Network Interface Card, or NIC, represents a network interface that can be associated to a virtual machine (VM).
trans-unit.target: Network Interface Card, or NIC, represents a network interface that can be associated to a virtual machine (VM).

trans-unit.source: A VM can have one or more NICs.
trans-unit.target: A VM can have one or more NICs.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>NIC's on a single VM</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>NIC's on a single VM</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Key properties of a NIC resource include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of a NIC resource include:

trans-unit.source: IP settings
trans-unit.target: IP settings

trans-unit.source: A NIC can also be associated with the following network resources:
trans-unit.target: A NIC can also be associated with the following network resources:

trans-unit.source: Network Security Group (NSG)
trans-unit.target: Network Security Group (NSG)

trans-unit.source: Load balancer
trans-unit.target: Load balancer

trans-unit.source: Virtual Network and Subnet
trans-unit.target: Virtual Network and Subnet

trans-unit.source: Virtual Networks (VNET) and subnets help define a security boundary for workloads running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Virtual Networks (VNET) and subnets help define a security boundary for workloads running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: A VNET is characterized by an address space, also referred to as CIDR block.
trans-unit.target: A VNET is characterized by an address space, also referred to as CIDR block.

trans-unit.source: A subnet is a child resource of a VNET, and helps define segments of address spaces within a CIDR block, using IP address prefixes.
trans-unit.target: A subnet is a child resource of a VNET, and helps define segments of address spaces within a CIDR block, using IP address prefixes.

trans-unit.source: VMs that execute various workloads essentially operate in a subnet boundary.
trans-unit.target: VMs that execute various workloads essentially operate in a subnet boundary.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>NIC's on a single VM</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>NIC's on a single VM</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Key properties of a VNET resource include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of a VNET resource include:

trans-unit.source: IP address space (CIDR block)
trans-unit.target: IP address space (CIDR block)

trans-unit.source: VNET name
trans-unit.target: VNET name

trans-unit.source: subnets
trans-unit.target: subnets

trans-unit.source: A VNET can also be associated with the following network resources:
trans-unit.target: A VNET can also be associated with the following network resources:

trans-unit.source: VPN Gateway
trans-unit.target: VPN Gateway

trans-unit.source: Key properties of a subnet include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of a subnet include:

trans-unit.source: IP address prefix
trans-unit.target: IP address prefix

trans-unit.source: Subnet name
trans-unit.target: Subnet name

trans-unit.source: A subnet can also be associated with the following network resources:
trans-unit.target: A subnet can also be associated with the following network resources:

trans-unit.source: NSG
trans-unit.target: NSG

trans-unit.source: Load Balancer
trans-unit.target: Load Balancer

trans-unit.source: A load balancer is used when you want to scale your applications.
trans-unit.target: A load balancer is used when you want to scale your applications.

trans-unit.source: Typical deployment scenarios involve applications running on multiple VM instances.
trans-unit.target: Typical deployment scenarios involve applications running on multiple VM instances.

trans-unit.source: The VM instances are fronted by a load balancer that helps to distribute network traffic to the various instances.
trans-unit.target: The VM instances are fronted by a load balancer that helps to distribute network traffic to the various instances.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>NIC's on a single VM</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>NIC's on a single VM</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Load balancers contain the following child resources:
trans-unit.target: Load balancers contain the following child resources:

trans-unit.source: Front end IP configuration – a Load balancer can include one or more front end IP addresses, otherwise known as a virtual IPs (VIPs).
trans-unit.target: Front end IP configuration – a Load balancer can include one or more front end IP addresses, otherwise known as a virtual IPs (VIPs).

trans-unit.source: These IP addresses serve as ingress for the traffic.
trans-unit.target: These IP addresses serve as ingress for the traffic.

trans-unit.source: Backend address pool – these are IP addresses associated with the VM NICs to which load will be distributed.
trans-unit.target: Backend address pool – these are IP addresses associated with the VM NICs to which load will be distributed.

trans-unit.source: Load balancing rules – a rule property maps a given front end IP and port combination to a set of back end IP addresses and port combination.
trans-unit.target: Load balancing rules – a rule property maps a given front end IP and port combination to a set of back end IP addresses and port combination.

trans-unit.source: With a single definition of a load balancer resource, you can define multiple load balancing rules, each rule reflecting a combination of a front end IP and port and back end IP and port associated with VMs.
trans-unit.target: With a single definition of a load balancer resource, you can define multiple load balancing rules, each rule reflecting a combination of a front end IP and port and back end IP and port associated with VMs.

trans-unit.source: Probes – probes enable you to keep track of the health of VM instances.
trans-unit.target: Probes – probes enable you to keep track of the health of VM instances.

trans-unit.source: If a health probe fails, the VM instance will be taken out of rotation automatically.
trans-unit.target: If a health probe fails, the VM instance will be taken out of rotation automatically.

trans-unit.source: Inbound NAT rules – NAT rules defining the inbound traffic flowing through the front end IP and distributed to the back end IP.
trans-unit.target: Inbound NAT rules – NAT rules defining the inbound traffic flowing through the front end IP and distributed to the back end IP.

trans-unit.source: Public IP
trans-unit.target: Public IP

trans-unit.source: A public IP address resource provides either a reserved or dynamic public IP address.
trans-unit.target: A public IP address resource provides either a reserved or dynamic public IP address.

trans-unit.source: A Public IP address can be assigned to a load balancer, NAT, or associated with a private IP address on a NIC of a VM.
trans-unit.target: A Public IP address can be assigned to a load balancer, NAT, or associated with a private IP address on a NIC of a VM.

trans-unit.source: Key properties of a public IP resource include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of a public IP resource include:

trans-unit.source: IP allocation method – reserved or dynamic.
trans-unit.target: IP allocation method – reserved or dynamic.

trans-unit.source: Network Security Group (NSG)
trans-unit.target: Network Security Group (NSG)

trans-unit.source: An NSG resource enables the creation of security boundary for workloads, by implementing allow and deny rules.
trans-unit.target: An NSG resource enables the creation of security boundary for workloads, by implementing allow and deny rules.

trans-unit.source: Such rules can be applied at the NIC level (VM instance level) or at the subnet level (group of VMs).
trans-unit.target: Such rules can be applied at the NIC level (VM instance level) or at the subnet level (group of VMs).

trans-unit.source: Key properties of NSG resource include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of NSG resource include:

trans-unit.source: Security rule - An NSG can have multiple security rules defined.
trans-unit.target: Security rule - An NSG can have multiple security rules defined.

trans-unit.source: Each rule can allow or deny different types of traffic.
trans-unit.target: Each rule can allow or deny different types of traffic.

trans-unit.source: Security Rule
trans-unit.target: Security Rule

trans-unit.source: A security rule is a child resource of an NSG.
trans-unit.target: A security rule is a child resource of an NSG.

trans-unit.source: Key properties of a Security rule include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of a Security rule include:

trans-unit.source: Protocol – network protocol this rule applies to.
trans-unit.target: Protocol – network protocol this rule applies to.

trans-unit.source: Source Port Range - source port, or range from, 0 to 65535.
trans-unit.target: Source Port Range - source port, or range from, 0 to 65535.

trans-unit.source: A wildcard can be used to match all ports.
trans-unit.target: A wildcard can be used to match all ports.

trans-unit.source: Destination Port Range - Destination port, or range, from 0 to 65535.
trans-unit.target: Destination Port Range - Destination port, or range, from 0 to 65535.

trans-unit.source: A wildcard can be used to match all ports.
trans-unit.target: A wildcard can be used to match all ports.

trans-unit.source: Source Address Prefix – source IP address range.
trans-unit.target: Source Address Prefix – source IP address range.

trans-unit.source: Destination Address Prefix – destination IP address range.
trans-unit.target: Destination Address Prefix – destination IP address range.

trans-unit.source: Access – Allow or Deny traffic.
trans-unit.target: Access – Allow or Deny traffic.

trans-unit.source: Priority – a value between 100 and 4096.
trans-unit.target: Priority – a value between 100 and 4096.

trans-unit.source: The priority number must be unique for each rule in collection of security rules.
trans-unit.target: The priority number must be unique for each rule in collection of security rules.

trans-unit.source: The lower the priority number, the higher the priority of the rule.
trans-unit.target: The lower the priority number, the higher the priority of the rule.

trans-unit.source: Direction – specifies if the rule will be applied to traffic in the Inbound or Outbound direction.
trans-unit.target: Direction – specifies if the rule will be applied to traffic in the Inbound or Outbound direction.

trans-unit.source: VPN Gateway
trans-unit.target: VPN Gateway

trans-unit.source: A VPN gateway resource enables you to create a secure connection between their on-premises data center and Azure.
trans-unit.target: A VPN gateway resource enables you to create a secure connection between their on-premises data center and Azure.

trans-unit.source: A VPN gateway resource can be configured in three different ways:
trans-unit.target: A VPN gateway resource can be configured in three different ways:

trans-unit.source: Point to Site – you can securely access your Azure resources hosted in a VNET by using a VPN client from any computer.
trans-unit.target: Point to Site – you can securely access your Azure resources hosted in a VNET by using a VPN client from any computer.

trans-unit.source: Multi-site connection – you can securely connect from your on-premises data centers to resources running in a VNET.
trans-unit.target: Multi-site connection – you can securely connect from your on-premises data centers to resources running in a VNET.

trans-unit.source: VNET to VNET – you can securely connect across Azure VNETS within the same region, or across regions to build workloads with geo-redundancy.
trans-unit.target: VNET to VNET – you can securely connect across Azure VNETS within the same region, or across regions to build workloads with geo-redundancy.

trans-unit.source: Key properties of a VPN gateway include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of a VPN gateway include:

trans-unit.source: Gateway type - dynamically routed or a static routed gateway.
trans-unit.target: Gateway type - dynamically routed or a static routed gateway.

trans-unit.source: VPN Client Address Pool Prefix – IP addresses to be assigned to clients connecting in a point to site configuration.
trans-unit.target: VPN Client Address Pool Prefix – IP addresses to be assigned to clients connecting in a point to site configuration.

trans-unit.source: Traffic Manager Profile
trans-unit.target: Traffic Manager Profile

trans-unit.source: Traffic manager and its child endpoint resource enable distribution of your traffic to endpoints in Azure and outside of Azure.
trans-unit.target: Traffic manager and its child endpoint resource enable distribution of your traffic to endpoints in Azure and outside of Azure.

trans-unit.source: Such traffic distribution is governed by policies.
trans-unit.target: Such traffic distribution is governed by policies.

trans-unit.source: Traffic manager also allows endpoint health to be monitored, and traffic diverted appropriately based on the health of an endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Traffic manager also allows endpoint health to be monitored, and traffic diverted appropriately based on the health of an endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Key properties of a traffic manager profile include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of a traffic manager profile include:

trans-unit.source: Traffic routing method - possible values are Performance, Weighted, and Priority.
trans-unit.target: Traffic routing method - possible values are Performance, Weighted, and Priority.

trans-unit.source: DNS configuration - FQDN for the profile.
trans-unit.target: DNS configuration - FQDN for the profile.

trans-unit.source: Protocol - monitoring protocol, possible values are HTTP and HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Protocol - monitoring protocol, possible values are HTTP and HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: Port - monitoring port.
trans-unit.target: Port - monitoring port.

trans-unit.source: Path - monitoring path.
trans-unit.target: Path - monitoring path.

trans-unit.source: Endpoints - container for endpoint resources.
trans-unit.target: Endpoints - container for endpoint resources.

trans-unit.source: Endpoint
trans-unit.target: Endpoint

trans-unit.source: An endpoint is a child resource of a Traffic Manager Profile.
trans-unit.target: An endpoint is a child resource of a Traffic Manager Profile.

trans-unit.source: It represents a service or web endpoint to which user traffic is distributed based on the configured policy in the Traffic Manager Profile resource.
trans-unit.target: It represents a service or web endpoint to which user traffic is distributed based on the configured policy in the Traffic Manager Profile resource.

trans-unit.source: Key properties of an endpoint include:
trans-unit.target: Key properties of an endpoint include:

trans-unit.source: Type - the type of the endpoint, possible values are Azure End point, External Endpoint, and Nested Endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Type - the type of the endpoint, possible values are Azure End point, External Endpoint, and Nested Endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Target Resource ID – public IP address of a service or web endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Target Resource ID – public IP address of a service or web endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This can be an Azure or external endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This can be an Azure or external endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Weight - endpoint weight used in traffic management.
trans-unit.target: Weight - endpoint weight used in traffic management.

trans-unit.source: Priority - priority of the endpoint, used to define a failover action.
trans-unit.target: Priority - priority of the endpoint, used to define a failover action.

trans-unit.source: Using a template
trans-unit.target: Using a template

trans-unit.source: You can deploy services to Azure from a template by using PowerShell, AzureCLI, or by performing a click to deploy from GitHub.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy services to Azure from a template by using PowerShell, AzureCLI, or by performing a click to deploy from GitHub.

trans-unit.source: To deploy services from a template in GitHub, execute the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To deploy services from a template in GitHub, execute the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Open the template3 file from GitHub.
trans-unit.target: Open the template3 file from GitHub.

trans-unit.source: As an example, open <link><linkText>Virtual network with two subnets</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: As an example, open <link><linkText>Virtual network with two subnets</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click on Deploy to Azure, and then sign in on to the Azure portal with your credentials.
trans-unit.target: Click on Deploy to Azure, and then sign in on to the Azure portal with your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Verify the template, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: Verify the template, and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: Click Edit parameters and select a location, such as West US, for the vnet and subnets.
trans-unit.target: Click Edit parameters and select a location, such as West US, for the vnet and subnets.

trans-unit.source: If necessary, change the ADDRESSPREFIX and SUBNETPREFIX parameters, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: If necessary, change the ADDRESSPREFIX and SUBNETPREFIX parameters, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Click Select a resource group and then click on the resource group you want to add the vnet and subnets to.
trans-unit.target: Click Select a resource group and then click on the resource group you want to add the vnet and subnets to.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can create a new resource group by clicking Or create new.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can create a new resource group by clicking Or create new.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: Notice the tile displaying Provisioning Template deployment.
trans-unit.target: Notice the tile displaying Provisioning Template deployment.

trans-unit.source: Once the deployment is done, you will see a screen similar to one below.
trans-unit.target: Once the deployment is done, you will see a screen similar to one below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Sample template deployment</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Sample template deployment</linkText>

trans-unit.source: See Also
trans-unit.target: See Also

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Networking API reference</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Networking API reference</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell reference for networking</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell reference for networking</linkText><title></title></link>
